Context:
Students who have completed courses at another accredited post-secondary institution or at George Brown College may be eligible for advanced standing or transfer credits to higher levels or semesters in various programs. The eligibility for transfer credits depends on the academic grades received in the previous studies and the availability of space in the program. Students must possess the required prerequisites and meet the minimum grade requirements for each specific course in the program to be granted an exemption (transfer credit). The transferred courses are not recorded as graded courses and are not used in the calculation of the student's GPA. George Brown College reserves the right to assess transfer credits on an individual basis and make changes in rules, regulations, and policies as required.

For Degree Program Transfers:
- Students must have received a C (63% or higher) for degree level or University courses or a B (70% or higher) in a Certificate or Diploma level at an accredited community college/institute of technology courses to be eligible for transfer credits to a degree level program.

For Continuing Education, Certificate & Diploma Program Transfers:
- Students who have completed studies at another accredited post-secondary institution or at George Brown College must have received the required grades. The details are not explicitly stated in the text.

Transfer credits are shown as an EX (Exemption) on a student's record, and internal transfer credits are applied from the original program to the new program and calculated in the GPA. For more information regarding course and block transfer credits, visit the Transfer Guide on George Brown College's website.
file_path: scraped_pages/otherpages/Frequently Asked Questions About Transfer Guide and Exemptions | George Brown College.txt

Context:
The text provides information about transfer credits, exemptions, GPA calculation, advanced standing, block transfer, and articulation agreements at George Brown College. Here's the extracted information:

1. Transfer credit or exemption: A transfer credit from another institution is recorded as an exemption (EX) on the student record and not included in the GPA calculation.
2. Grading system: The grade points are the product of the value of the letter grade and the course credit. The GPA is the sum of the course grade points for all courses divided by the sum of the course credits.
3. Advanced standing: It is a process that enables entry to a semester higher than semester one at George Brown College. Students applying for advanced standing are granted block credits for previous courses taken in a related area of study, which allows them to enter the second semester or higher of a program. The advanced standing grade (AS) is assigned to all courses for the semester for which a block transfer is granted and is not calculated in the student's GPA.
4. Articulation agreements: These are formal agreements between institutions that allow transfer of credits from a specific program at one institution to be applied towards advanced standing or entry at another institution. Students can use these agreements to move between different programs, institutions, and credentials. George Brown College has signed articulation agreements with various institutions, which can be found in the Transfer Agreements and Opportunities Database.
5. Block transfer opportunities: These are pathways that allow students to transfer blocks of credits without a formal articulation agreement. An example at George Brown is that a graduate from any Architectural Technology program in Ontario can be granted advanced standing.
6. Contact information: To learn more about applying for advanced standing, contact the Admissions Office at 416 415-5000 ext. 4805. For more information on policies related to transfer credits, advanced standing, and articulation agreements, see the Office of the Registrar Policies.
file_path: scraped_pages/otherpages/Frequently Asked Questions About Transfer Guide and Exemptions | George Brown College.txt

Context:
* A graduate from any Architectural Technology program in Ontario can apply to semester 4 of the Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) program at George Brown.
* To determine potential transfer credits, students can use the Course-to-Course Equivalencies Database, Transfer Agreements and Opportunities Database, or Guide to Selecting Courses Eligible for Transfer Credit.
* Students must be enrolled at George Brown College to receive an official assessment of their previous education and be granted transfer credits.
* Application for transfer credits can be made through STU-VIEW in the term the student is scheduled to attend the course, with exceptions for general education/liberal studies electives which can be applied for in any one term.
* Required documents for transfer credit assessment include an official transcript and a course outline or syllabus.
* For more information on continuing education transfer credits, students should visit the Continuing Education website.
* Students with international education may have additional requirements.
file_path: scraped_pages/otherpages/Frequently Asked Questions About Transfer Guide and Exemptions | George Brown College.txt

Context:
* Applications for George Brown College require a course outline to be attached, which can be uploaded through the college's website.
* The Transfer Credit Office cannot upload and attach course outlines.
* If an application is submitted on the last day without a course outline, arrangements must be made with the Transfer Credit Office.
* To obtain course outlines, refer to Ontario Colleges Course Outlines (with links) for a list of colleges and methods to acquire them.
* A minimum grade of 60% is generally required to receive a transfer credit, but some courses may have higher minimum grades.
* Due to Covid-19 restrictions, the Transfer Credit Office is not processing mailed transcripts.
* Official transcripts can be submitted by emailing a PDF copy to transfercredit@georgebrown.ca or through STU-VIEW if available.
* Applications without official transcripts are still accepted, but will be marked as incomplete until the transcript is received.
* To access a transcript, an application must be created and submitted.
* If a transcript is not available on an application, contact transfercredit@georgebrown.ca with student ID number and previous institution name.
* The course outline is necessary for faculty to determine equivalency of courses.
* If unable to obtain a course outline, notify transfercredit@georgebrown.ca by email.
file_path: scraped_pages/otherpages/Frequently Asked Questions About Transfer Guide and Exemptions | George Brown College.txt

Context:
* To obtain a course outline for transfer credit application, email transfercredit@georgebrown.ca with student ID number.
* If "Grade Verification Required" in Comments column, no course outline required.
* Ontario Colleges Course Outlines list and instructions available online.
* Departmental decision on late applications, contact Academic department.
* Must be registered and attending the course until decision is entered.
* Can check application status in STU-VIEW, Registration Services, Registration.
* Contacted by email for any status-impacting questions or formal decision.
* Transfer credit accepted through specific process, see "How to Accept an Approved Transfer Credit".
* Transfer credit applied to account after last day to register if approved.
* Electives: Can drop if not accepting transfer credit.

Context:
* Students can use transfer credits for electives or apply them to a future term after the last day to register.
* The college will apply approved transfer credits to students' accounts.
* Students must email transfercredit@georgebrown.ca with their Student ID number if they wish to remain registered in a course after the application closes.
* Faculty make decisions on transfer credit applications one week after the application deadline, and decisions are final but reviewable.
* Advanced standing is typically granted for an entire semester of courses from another institution, and these courses cannot be used for further transfer credits.
* The minimum number of courses students must complete at George Brown College varies depending on their program:
  * Full-time programs: 25%
  * Continuing Education programs: 50%.
* Students can submit a Transfer Credit Application through STU-VIEW if they feel they could receive transfer credits for additional courses.
* Contact information for specific academic departments:
  * LASelectives@georgebrown.ca (for elective programs)
  * comm@georgebrown.ca (for College English/Communications).
file_path: scraped_pages/otherpages/Frequently Asked Questions About Transfer Guide and Exemptions | George Brown College.txt

Context:
* George Brown College is where the declared program of study must be earned.
* In a full-time post-secondary program, up to 75% of total course requirements can be transferred as credits, with limitations for certain Postgraduate Level Programs.
* Breadth Requirement: students are required to complete general education courses from three categories: Humanities, Social Science, and Science. The number of transfer credits that can be received in any one category is limited to meet the breadth requirements.
* Students must maintain full-time status and can receive up to two transfer credits per term while still being considered full-time students.
* A Course-to-Course Equivalency Database is available to help determine equivalent courses. Limited data is currently available for international institutions.
* To apply for transfer credits, students should review the "Guide to Selecting Courses Eligible for Transfer Credit" and submit an application through STU-VIEW. The college will evaluate course outlines and official transcripts.
* In most cases, courses must have been taken at the previous institution within the last 5 years to qualify for transfer credits. Some exceptions may apply where the time limit differs in specialized programs.
file_path: scraped_pages/otherpages/Frequently Asked Questions About Transfer Guide and Exemptions | George Brown College.txt

Context:
* Time limit for transfer of courses varies depending on the program, some programs have a time limit of 2 years. (Contact Academic Department for specific program information.)
* Application can be made for English and elective courses taken outside of the 5-year limitation.
* Course outlines are required for evaluation of transferred courses.
* Assistance in determining which previous courses meet general education/liberal studies elective requirements can be found on the website.
* Database of courses that grant generic general elective or liberal studies transfer credit is available online.
* Acceptance of international educational institutions for transfer credit with more information available on their I have International Education page.
* Automatically transferred internal transfer credits include college English and general education and liberal studies electives.
* Credits from previous full-time programs or continuing education can be applied to a new program through the use of CAPP – Credential Evaluation or "What-If" analysis tools.
* If courses are not applied to the new program, contact the Academic Department for review.
* Articulation agreements or pathways exist between some George Brown programs.
* Eligible students may register in another full-time post-secondary course with the same number of hours at no additional charge to replace a course they no longer need. (Subject to course availability and class space.)
* Prior Learning Assessment and Recognition is available for evaluating work experience, which will be graded as it would be in a classroom environment.
* It's recommended to begin the Prior Learning Assessment and Recognition process at least 3 months prior to the actual start date of the course.
file_path: scraped_pages/otherpages/Frequently Asked Questions About Transfer Guide and Exemptions | George Brown College.txt

Context:
* It is recommended that students begin the application process at least 3 months before their course start date.
* Full-time students are defined as taking 66% or 2/3 of the required courses in a semester.
* Students can have up to two exemptions in one term before dropping to part-time status, affecting tuition fees and OSAP eligibility.
* Part-time students have less than a 60% course load.
* George Brown College diploma is accepted at many local, national, and international postsecondary institutions.
* Transfer Agreements and Opportunities Database contains transfer agreements and opportunities for George Brown students and graduates.
* For policy and procedures information, contact transfercredit@georgebrown.ca or call 416-415-2000.
* Application deadlines, college news, upcoming events, tours, and more can be signed up for on the website.
* Contact ask.george@georgebrown.ca or visit social media hub for further information.
* The information contained in the website is subject to change without notice.
* Students are responsible for verifying George Brown College fee requirements.
* Contact numbers: 416-415-2000, TTY: 1-877-515-5559.
* Emails: transfercredit@georgebrown.ca, ask.george@georgebrown.ca.
* Websites: ontransfer.ca, individual educational institutions that interest you.
